title: The association between VO2 max and cardiorespiratory fitness
content: In this AMA episode, Peter and Bob discuss the longevity benefits from greater cardiorespiratory fitness (CRF) and greater muscle mass and strength. They talk about VO2 max and its association with cardiorespiratory fitness.

title: The impact of declining fitness levels with age
content: Peter and Bob dive deep into the literature showing a rapid increase in morbidity and mortality risk as fitness levels decline with age. They discuss changing mortality risk based on VO2 max and cardiorespiratory fitness, and the profound impact of improving cardiorespiratory fitness.

title: Muscle mass, function, and loss with aging
content: Peter and Bob discuss muscle mass, function, and loss with aging, how it’s defined, measured, and the cutoff points for sarcopenia. They also talk about the increasing mortality risk associated with declining muscle mass and strength, and evaluate the cumulative impact of cardiorespiratory fitness and muscular strength on mortality risk when put together.

title: The impact of fasting on muscle mass
content: Peter and Bob discuss the impact of fasting on muscle mass and the potential tradeoffs to consider. They emphasize the critical importance of working to maintain muscle mass and strength as we age.

title: VO2 max and its association with cardiorespiratory fitness
content: The most common thing in the literature is either METs, metabolic equivalents or VO2 max. For a VO2 max test, you are hooked up to an indirect calorimeter—a device that provides complete occlusion around your mouth and your nose so you’re only breathing through your mouth. The device has two sensors on it. One sensor measures the concentration of oxygen that is being expelled. The other one is also measuring the concentration of carbon dioxide that’s expelled. Knowing those two things gives you a “flow rate” — VO2 and a VCO2. This can tell you how much energy you’re utilizing via something called the Fick principle. But now what we’re talking about is something different which is… what is the maximum utilization of oxygen?

title: VO2 max and its measurement
content: VO2 max is a measure of the maximum amount of oxygen that a person can utilize during exercise. It is measured in liters per minute and then normalized by body weight to get milliliters per kilogram per minute. The fittest of the fit are going to be north of 80 milliliters of oxygen per kilogram per minute. The highest ever recorded VO2 max was a cyclist named Oskar Svendsen who measured about 96. Any sort of elite cardiac type athlete, a runner, cyclist, rower, those sorts of athletes, they’re generally going to be above 70.

title: Mortality risk and cardiorespiratory fitness
content: A study was conducted on a group of people that were 53 years old on average. They were ranked based on their VO2 max test results. The low fitness group had the highest mortality risk. Going from low to below average is a 50% reduction in mortality over a decade. Going from low to above average, it’s about a 60% or 70% reduction in mortality. If you compare someone of low fitness to elite, it is a five-fold difference in mortality over a decade. Improving cardiorespiratory fitness has a profound impact on reducing mortality risk.

title: Classification of Cardiorespiratory Fitness
content: Cardiorespiratory fitness can be classified based on age and sex. Figure 3 shows the classification of cardiorespiratory fitness by age and sex.

title: VO2 max and METs
content: For each age, gender combo, we’re showing two pieces of information – i)  METs and ii) VO2 max There is a linear relationship between those two and an exact multiple 3.5. If you know how many METs you can hold for three minutes, then you multiply that by 3.5 and that’s your VO2 max.

title: VO2 max goals and training protocol
content: Peter wants everybody to have a VO2 max test so that he can benchmark them on their way to their “Centenarian Decathlon”. Peter tends to just rely on the VO2 max because it’s just more objective. For someone looking at this through a longevity lens, you’re not going to want to do what I used to do or what somebody who’s training for a specific sport. I am now only doing VO2 max training from the standpoint of longevity benefit, not because I’m trying to do well in a Masters race. Once a week, I will do a VO2 max sort of specific ride—typically something where you’re doing two to four minute intervals that are at the highest level that you can go for two to four minutes. It’s typically done at about a one-to-one ratio of work to recovery. You don’t need to do a whole heck of a lot of it. I might do this for only 20 minutes…I typically pair it with a Zone 2 day.

title: The dramatic drop off with age
content: Take a look at the elite column and look at the VO2 max in the elite column, and look at how precipitously it falls. Going from the second decade of life to the third, the third to the fourth, the fourth to the fifth, the fifth to the sixth, very little fall. Then look what happens, big fall, bigger fall, bigger fall. We know this based on the difference between how people perform in endurance activities versus explosive strength activities as they age. We see a greater ability to maintain cardiorespiratory fitness at a Masters level as you age and a lower level to maintain explosivity and strength as you age due really to the shift from Type II to Type I fibers.

title: “Elite” doesn’t mean “elite athlete”
content: Don’t confuse this for elite athlete — This is just the characteristic that was given to a general population that fall in the top ~2.5% of the population. Each time you move from one of these groups to the next, you get a statistically significant benefit. But the benefit gets less with each bump—You’re always going to want to go to the right and up, meaning increase your fitness and mimic that of somebody younger.

title: The Importance of Cardiovascular Fitness
content: The most important thing is getting out of that low and/or below average group you get such an advantage of getting out of that group—it’s more beneficial than if a smoker quit smoking.

title: Sarcopenia and Aging
content: Sarcopenia is one of the more inevitable aspects of aging—”probably the worst gravity of aging”. Basically, as a result of aging, we’re seeing more low grade inflammation, more oxidative stress, impaired regenerative capacity, impaired muscle protein synthesis. We replace our Type II muscle fibers—more contractile function—with fat and connective tissue. The net result is we are losing two things, i) the structural component of the muscle—the loss of the actual contractile function, and ii) the metabolic myocyte function. That’s why it’s accompanied by more insulin resistance, less glucose disposal, greater tendency to diabetes.

title: Measuring Muscle Mass
content: But how do you measure muscle mass? You could get an accurate measure by using a CT scan or an MRI to do that, but they are not good options practically speaking. Gold standard today is Dual X-ray absorptiometry (DXA or DEXA). While it’s not quite as accurate as CT and MRI, it does allow you to come up with an approximation of total muscle mass by just looking at the appendices (or appendicular lean mass (ALM)). Another common way—which probably is less accurate—is Bioelectrical Impedance Analysis, BIA.

title: Appendicular Lean Mass
content: Using DEXA scans, appendicular lean mass can be measured and normalized by height to get a number in kilograms per meter squared. The range in the population is wide, with the most muscular individuals being around 8.5 for women and 10.5 for men. Women tend to hold a higher percentage of their muscle mass below their waist. Peter Attia's ALMI was just below nine on his last DEXA, and he wants to bulk up his arms and legs more.

title: Sarcopenia Cutoff Points
content: The sarcopenia cutoff points are based on the appendicular skeletal muscle mass or appendicular skeletal mass index. For men, the cutoff is below 7.0 kilograms per meter squared, and for women, it's less than 5.5 kilograms per meters squared. There are also cutoff points for low strength by 'chair stand' and 'grip strength'.

title: Mortality Risk Associated with Declining Muscle Mass and Strength
content: A meta-analysis in 2017 found that people with sarcopenia had a 60% increase in the relative risk of death compared to people without. The weight of the studies is based on how many people were in the study and there weren’t a lot of women. The females are weighted lower because it’s a lower sample size, which played a role here as far as how it was weighted. Another study looked at muscle mass and muscle strength and the relationship between the two and whether you can tease anything out between them.

title: Methods of Measuring Muscle Mass
content: The different ways that they’re measuring the lean mass include calf circumference or calf circ, skeletal muscle, and mid-arm muscle circumference. They have equations where they try to basically validate and test those things compared to a DEXA to try to get an estimate for the appendicular lean mass. MAMC is short for mid-arm muscle circumference. They take the circumference with a tape measure and then they also will get your tricep skinfold thickness. There’s a little bit of an adjustment there for fat mass when they’re looking at that.

title: Associations of LMM and LMS with ACM
content: A study looked at muscle mass and muscle strength and the relationship between the two and whether you can tease anything out between them. For LMM, the appendicular lean mass in an absolute term was not a predictor of mortality, though there was a trend towards it. And when you normalize by BMI, there was a 47% increase in all-cause mortality, but it was not statistically significant. Figures B and C that are the really interesting ones here.

title: Muscle size vs. strength—which has the bigger impact on mortality risk?
content: The study found that low muscle strength was independently associated with increased risk for mortality. If you have low muscle mass, provided you have adequate strength, you’re okay. Having big muscles is great for show but it turns out that it’s what those muscles can do that probably matters more, at least in this analysis. Be less concerned with the size of your muscles and be more concerned with how strong you are.

title: How much lean mass and strength are people losing by time?
content: The lowest rate of decline that Peter could see is 1% per year. Another study showed 1.3% per year. Others are sort of putting it at one to 2% per year after 50. Loss of 35 to 40% between age 20 and 80. And the strength losses might even be greater. Some studies even showing 4% strength loss per year. It’s very difficult to put that in context when you understand what compounding does.

title: The importance of strength, muscle mass, and cardiorespiratory fitness
content: Either through cardiorespiratory fitness, strength, or probably even muscle mass, to some extent, given its association with strength, you’ve got to be strong. You’ve got to have muscle mass to accompany that strength. You’ve got to have the cardiorespiratory fitness.

title: Muscle strength and mortality risk
content: The study looked at men and women leg strength versus grip strength (a leg extension and a grip exercise). The leg strength, they did it in newton meters. The grip strength is in kilograms.

title: Importance of Leg Strength in Men
content: Men's leg strength is an important factor in mortality risk. The weaker the leg strength, the quicker the mortality risk increases. When strength metric is normalized by muscle size, a reduction of 0.2 units in CT area or 0.34 units in DEXA leads to a 26% or 39% increase in mortality, respectively. Reduction in grip strength, normalized by DEXA arm measurement, leads to a 23% increase in mortality. These findings were statistically significant.

title: Leg Strength in Women
content: Although statistically significant, leg strength in women had a higher confidence interval. Table four in the show notes provides an easier way to appreciate the statistical relevance of this.

title: Importance of Cardiorespiratory Fitness and Muscular Strength
content: Cardiorespiratory fitness and muscular strength are both important in reducing mortality risk. Improving cardiorespiratory fitness gives a bigger bang for your buck if you have low strength. However, doing both is better than doing one or the other. These findings were statistically significant.

title: Limitations of the Data Points
content: The data points do not capture quality of life and the ability to perform activities that one enjoys in their later years.

title: The Importance of Strength and Cardiovascular Fitness
content: Peter emphasizes that being in the highest group of both strength and cardiorespiratory fitness is crucial for enjoying life later on. This is especially important to consider when investigating the rising incidence in deaths from falls and what role Alzheimer's disease might play.

title: The Increase in Mortality from Falls
content: From 2007 to 2016, the deaths per 100,000 in the United States as a result of falls went from about 46 to 60, which is a 30% increase. By 2030, we're going to see seven fall deaths every hour. The leading cause of traumatic brain injury is unintentional falling, which exceeds that of even motor vehicle accidents.

title: Fasting and Muscle Mass
content: When considering fasting and caloric restriction, it's important to think about the tradeoff between building and preserving muscle. Prolonged fasting can result in a catabolic hit, which can lead to a loss in muscle size. It's crucial to be thoughtful about how fasting is used as a tool, as some patients should never be fasting.

title: Fasting and Muscle Mass
content: Fasting can be beneficial for improving insulin sensitivity and glucose regulation, but it may not be worth the trade-off for patients who need to be more anabolic to get bigger and stronger. For those who are overweight, fasting can be a useful tool, but it's important to understand that muscle mass may be lost in the process. It's crucial to evaluate fasting in the context of where you are and to find other ways to get the metabolic benefits if you are in shouting distance of sarcopenia.

title: Maintaining Muscle Mass and Strength as We Age
content: The Paddon-Jones curve shows that there is a staggered decline in muscle mass and size as we age, and it can accelerate if we are injured or bedridden. Having a muscle reserve is important for physiological headroom, especially in case of disease or injury. Waiting until you're older to start building muscle can be disastrous, so it's important to work on maintaining muscle mass and strength as we age.

title: The Effects of COVID on Deconditioning
content: COVID has had a significant deconditioning effect on people who have been hospitalized. A study showed that just a few weeks of inactivity can take away a year's worth of muscle mass gained through heavy training. Exercise is like a pill that you can't afford to skip too often or consistently. It's important to find a way to enjoy exercise to maximize cardiorespiratory fitness and strength.
